clawutil package¶

Submodules¶

clawutil.chardiff module¶

Module to perform charcter-wise diff of two files or a set of identically named files in two directories.

Can by used from the command line via:
python chardiff.py file1 file2 python chardiff.py dir1 dir2 python chardiff.py dir1 dir2 [‘fort.q*’,’*.data’]

The last example only compares the files with the specified pattern. Other optional arguments can also be specified.

Command line flags include:
-v, –verbose = Verbose output -h, –help = Display this help
exception clawutil.chardiff.Usage(msg)[source]¶

Bases: Exception

clawutil.chardiff.chardiff_dir(dir1, dir2, dir3='_char_diff', file_pattern='all', regression_test_files='all', overwrite=False, print_all_lines=True, verbose=True)[source]¶

Run chardiff_file on all common files between dir1 and dir2 that match the patterns in the list files.

clawutil.claw_git_status module¶

Print status of all clawpack git repositories.

clawutil.claw_git_status.make_git_status_file(outdir=None)[source]¶

Print status of all clawpack git repositories. Creates 2 files:

outdir + ‘/claw_git_status.txt’
contains list of last commits, what branch is checked out, and a short version of git status.
outdir + ‘/claw_git_diffs.txt’
contains all diffs between current working state and last commits.
clawutil.claw_git_status.repository_diff(repository)[source]¶

Uses a series of system command line calls via the subprocess module.

Input:
  • repository (str) - Name of clawpack repository whose status is needed.
Output:
  • (str) - String with diff output
clawutil.claw_git_status.repository_status(repository)[source]¶

Return string representation of git status of repository

Uses a series of system command line calls via the subprocess module.

Input:
  • repository (str) - Name of clawpack repository whose status is needed.
Output:
  • (str) - String with status output

clawutil.data module¶

Data Module

Contains the general class definition and the subclasses of the Clawpack data objects.

Changes in 5.0:

Stripped down version of Data object, no longer keeps track of “owners”. Data classes are now subclasses of ClawData, which checks if attributes

already exist before setting.
class clawutil.data.ClawData(attributes=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Class to be subclassed when defining data objects that should have a limited set of allowed attributes. Useful to guard against typos or misrembering the names of expected attributes.

Resetting values of existing attributes is allowed as usual, but new attributes can only be added using the method add_attribute.

Trying to set a nonexistent attribute will raise an AttributeError exception, except for those starting with ‘_’.

add_attribute(name, value=None, add_to_list=True)[source]¶

Adds an attribute called name to the data object

If an attribute needs to be added to the object, this routine must be called or the attribute will not be written out.

Input:
  • name - (string) Name of the data attribute
  • value - (id) Value to set name to, defaults to None
add_attributes(arg_list, value=None)[source]¶

Add a list of attributes, each initialized to value.

attributes()[source]¶

Returns tuple of attribute names

close_data_file()[source]¶

Close output data file

data_write(name=None, value=None, alt_name=None, description='')[source]¶

Write out value to data file, in the form

value =: name   # [description]

Remove brackets and commas from lists, and replace booleans by T/F.

Input:
  • name - (string) normally a string defining the variable, if name==None, write a blank line.
  • description - (string) optional description
has_attribute(name)[source]¶

Check if this data object has the given attributes

Input:
  • name - (string) Name of attribute
Output:
  • (bool) - True if data object contains a data attribute name
iteritems()[source]¶

Returns an iterator of attributes and values from this object

Output:
  • (Iterator) Iterator over attributes and values
open_data_file(name, datasource='setrun.py')[source]¶

Open a data file and write a warning header. Warning header starts with ‘#’ character. These lines are skipped if data file is opened using the library routine opendatafile.

Input:
  • name - (string) Name of data file
  • datasource - (string) Source for the data
Output:
  • (file) - file object
read(path, force=False)[source]¶

Read and fill applicable data attributes.

Note that if the data attribute is not found an exception will be raised unless the force argument is set to True in which case a new attribute will be added.

remove_attributes(arg_list)[source]¶

Remove the listed attributes.

write(out_file, data_source='setrun.py')[source]¶

clawutil.data.get_remote_file(url, output_dir=None, file_name=None, force=False, verbose=False, ask_user=False, unpack=True)[source]¶

Fetch file located at url and store at output_dir.

Input:
  • url (path) - URL to file to be downloaded.
  • output_dir (path) - Directory that the remote file will be downloaded to. Defaults to the GeoClaw sratch directory defined by os.path.join(os.environ[‘CLAW’], ‘geoclaw’, ‘scratch’).
  • file_name (string) - Name of local file. This defaults to the name of the remote file.
  • force (bool) - Force downloading of remote file regardless of whether it exists locally or not. Default is False
  • verbose (bool) - Print out status information. Default is False
  • ask_user (bool) - Whether to ask the user if it is ok to download the file before proceeding. Default is False
Raises:

Exceptions are raised from the urllib module having to do with errors fetching the remote file. Please see its documentation for more details of the exceptions that can be raised.

Notes:

If fetching the file fails urllib does not always warn you so if errors occur it may be wise to check to make sure the downloaded file actually has content in it.

returns unarchived_output_path

clawutil.data.strip_archive_extensions(path, extensions=['tar', 'tgz', 'bz2', 'gz', 'zip'])[source]¶

Strip off archive extensions defined in extensions list.

Return stripped path calling this function recursively until all splitext does not provide an extension in the extensions list. Note that zip files store the names of the contained files in the archive and the returned path will more than likely not have the appropriate file suffix.

clawutil.git module¶

Clawpack GitHub utility functions module

Contains functions for cloning the repositories at www.github.com/clawpack and checking the status of the local repositories.

Available Functions:
 status - Checks the status of the local repositories clone - Clones git repositories from GitHub
exception clawutil.git.Usage(msg)[source]¶

Bases: Exception

clawutil.git.clone(repo, force=False, verbose=False)[source]¶

This function clones git repositories located at GitHub.

It first checks to make sure a directory of each name does not already exist unless force == True.

Input:
  • repos_list (list) - List of repositories to fetch, if empty then fetch
    all.
  • force (bool) - Whether to overwrite existing directories if present,
    (default == False).
clawutil.git.status(path=None)[source]¶

This function checks the status of the repository at path.

clawutil.imagediff module¶

Module to diff two images or directories full of images.

Can by used from the command line via:
python imagediff.py file1 file2 python imagediff.py dir1 dir2 [dir3]

In the latter case dir1 and dir2 are any two directories and all images will be compared. The optional dir3 argument gives the directory for the resulting diff’s and html files. Default is ‘_image_diff’.

Command line flags include:
-v, –verbose = Verbose output -r, –relocatable = Copy original image files to dir3 also -h, –help = Display this help
exception clawutil.imagediff.Usage(msg)[source]¶

Bases: Exception

clawutil.imagediff.imagediff_dir(dir1, dir2, dir3='_image_diff', ext='.png', regression_test_files='all', relocatable=False, overwrite=False, verbose=False)[source]¶

clawutil.make_all module¶

Performs ‘make all’ in each subdirectory to create sample results for the gallery or to perform regression tests against results in the gallery, or elsewhere.

Sends output and errors to separate files to simplify looking for errors.

clawutil.make_all.list_examples(examples_dir)[source]¶

Searches all subdirectories of examples_dir for examples and prints out a list.

clawutil.make_all.make_all(examples_dir='.', make_clean_first=False, env=None)[source]¶

clawutil.nbtools module¶

Useful tools for running Clawpack from an IPython notebook.

clawutil.nbtools.make_all(label=None, env=None, verbose=True)[source]¶

Perform ‘make all’ and display links

clawutil.nbtools.make_data(env=None, verbose=True)[source]¶

Perform ‘make data’ and display link.

clawutil.nbtools.make_driver(args, env, outfile, verbose)[source]¶

Use subprocess to run a make command and capture the output.

Input:
  • args: arguments to the make command
  • env: environment to run in (if None, use os.environ) Useful if $CLAW must be set in notebook.
  • outfile: file name of file for capturing stdout and stderr
  • vervose: if True, print out command and display link to output file

If the return code is non-zero, print a warning and link to output file regardless of value of verbose.

clawutil.nbtools.make_exe(new=False, env=None, verbose=True)[source]¶

Perform ‘make .exe’ and display link. If new = True, do ‘make new’ instead to force recompilation of everything.

clawutil.nbtools.make_htmls(outfile=None, env=None, verbose=False, readme_link=True)[source]¶

Perform ‘make .htmls’ and display link.

clawutil.nbtools.make_output(label=None, env=None, verbose=True)[source]¶

Perform ‘make output’ and display link.

clawutil.nbtools.make_output_and_plots(label=None, env=None, verbose=True)[source]¶
clawutil.nbtools.make_plots(label=None, env=None, verbose=True)[source]¶

Perform ‘make plots’ and display links

clawutil.runclaw module¶

clawutil.setenv module¶

Generate ClawPack environment variables for bash and csh

Checks to see which Clawpack projects/repositories have been downloaded by either checking in the CLAW directory (which defaults to the current directory) or by overridden paths set in the command line arguments.

exception clawutil.setenv.Usage(msg)[source]¶

Bases: Exception

clawutil.setenv.check_repos_dependencies(project_name, available_projects)[source]¶

Checks that required repositories of project_name are present

clawutil.setenv.write_environment_variable(csh_handle, bash_handle, var, value)[source]¶

clawutil.test module¶

clawutil.whichclaw module¶

Print out
  • settings of environment variables,
  • elements of sys.path that contain “clawpack”
  • lines of site-packages/easy-install.pth files that contain “clawpack”

Useful for figuring out how paths are set and which version of clawpack is being used when more than one has been installed.

Notes

  • this should be run in the users’ shell (which might not be bash)
  • this script has not been extensively tested, maybe it’s missing something
